Comment:
Hi everyone!

I was playing in a MT called New Year's Eve Party which was hosted by Master Chrisobee.  I found myself playing against a Master called Klauno (Klaus) and after he responded to my 1. e4 with the Sicilian (c4), I decided to play the Sicilian Grand Prix Attack and we ended up in Easy 19's Experimental Demolition Derby Attack line which involved a queen sac.  Unfortunately it went belly up for me but I thought I would annotate it so that whoever wants to be the white player in this line can see the refutation.  Here is Gameknot Analysis: http://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=17665124&rnd=0.444587956263756
5. Bc4 - shades of the Two Knights Defence where white plays g5 and Bc4 to worry the BK by attacking the square f7.

9. Bxg4 - I now have two pieces for Glenda and I have exposed the BK.  Over the next few moves I tie down black and attack!

11. Nc3 - swift development is called for.

12. Nd5+ - aggressive play but I do wish I had more white pieces in the vicinity of the BK.

13. Ndc7 - fork.
13. Ndc7 - fork.
15. Nxa8 - I didn't want to relax the bind but I felt I needed to get near material parity.  Unfortunately black's knight puts c2 under the hammer.

16. Kd1?? - a knee jerk reaction but I overlook Qh5+ forcing Henry back to e1 to face the vicious knight fork.  As I couldn't effectively block the check I resigned on the spot.  I should have played either f5 or 0-0.  Black would have still had an advantage but not enough to force resignation.  Although my rating got to within 17 points of 1900 I still have a lot to learn!
